wig okay
ready for day two please welcome to the
stage here this morning kicking us off
from Sophos Peter Gordon thank you and
good morning
so yes I'm Peter Gordon I'm a cloud
security architect with sofas and as you
can possibly guess from my accent I'm
actually from Australia today I'm going
to talk to you about how you can secure
the traffic leaving your V pcs on the
AWS cloud often security focuses on
traffic coming in from the outside but
it's also very important to make sure
that you secure traffic going to the
Internet as well now for those of you
who are familiar with the Sophos we're
at global cyber security vendor and
we've been around for over 30 years and
we've worked with AWS since 2011 in fact
we were also one of the first security
vendors to achieve the AWS advanced
technology partner security competency
now today I'd like to share a story with
you about one of our customers and the
solution they deployed in AWS to secure
their outbound traffic now this customer
is a large multinational and they have
several data centers around the world
and they made the decision that they
were going to close them all and in the
process migrate everything into AWS so
they're designed architecture and AWS
was going to cover multiple AWS regions
and V pcs for a variety of regulatory
and compliance reasons they hadn't need
to control and have visibility of all
outbound traffic from the V pcs so this
meant they needed a variety of security
controls including the stateful firewall
network address translation or or net
web content filtering and also
transparent proxy operationally they had
requirements around high availability
auto healing and auto scaling and with
paired v pcs there was also the need to
somehow send traffic across V PC pairing
connections and out to the Internet
securely
the limitation of transitive pairing
also had to be overcome and lastly
because of their DevOps requirements the
solution that they would go to select
ideally needed to be deployed via cope
so infrastructure as code so the
solution that our customer adopted
achieved all these requirements and more
it consisted of a small cluster of
unified threat management appliances or
UTM s deployed in a gateway type V PC
now these u teams were deployed using
AWS CloudFormation
which was great because that supported
their deployment via code requirement
once deployed these you teams were then
configured to provide the various
security controls required firstly was
the ability to control and log all
outbound traffic by using the firewall
function in the UTM network address
translation was also used to prevent
internal IP addresses from reaching
external servers and the web filtering
functionality in the UTM allows it to
actually examine a requested website
look at the category that site belongs
to and then make a decision as to
whether or not the internal ec2 instance
requesting that site there should be
allowed to get to it and and with that
transparent proxy was used so the the
company was able to avoid had the need
to accept the explicit proxy within
their ec2 instances
to allow the U teams to control traffic
originating from within paired VP sees
the second component of the solution was
to deploy what we call outbound gateways
or ogw s within each of the peered V pcs
now these outbound gateways are ec2
instances and they're deployed with
cloud formation and because there are
ec2 instances they can be used as
targets and route tables now to pass
traffic to the UTM s for filtering the
outbound gateways established GRE
tunnels with the worker u teams and the
worker u teams are the ones that handle
traffic going to and from the instances
and the other thing about these GRE
tunnels is that they can also go across
V PC parent connections so with the
outbound gateways and the UTM is
deployed the next step was to configure
the route tables for the internal
subnets so that they would use their
nearest outbound gateway as the target
for any traffic that was going to the
Internet so when an ec2 instance or for
that matter an AWS workspace tried to
connect to the internet their packets
are sent first to the outbound gateway
and then through the GRE tunnel to the
UTM workers which in turn inspect the
traffic and determine whether or not it
should be allowed to go out to the
Internet and if it is its passing it out
the destination so to put that into a
picture this is what the deployment
looks like with a single V PC so at the
top of the V PC we have an Internet
gateway and then immediately below that
we have a controller UTM this is like
the brain it's where we do all the
configuration on the UTM cluster now
that configuration is then stored
automatically in an s3 bucket and then
the other AZ we've got a subnet which
basically is empty but we can deploy a
replacement controller in the event that
the existing one fails and that's done
through an auto scaling group
at the same layer we also have what we
call these worker u teams as I mentioned
previously so they're handling the
traffic going to and from internal
instances now these workers when they
launch they obtain their configuration
from that s3 bucket that I mentioned
automatically so they can basically be
automatically configured at the drop of
a hat and below the U teams we have at
least one outbound gateway Parisi okay
once the outbound gateways are deployed
they will then established Giri tunnels
with each of the worker UTM s and below
the our bank gateways we have our
internal subnets containing our various
ec2 instances now the subnets internally
have route tables which will have a
route entry for 0.0 0.0 / 0 and where
the target is the nearest outbound
gateway and finally if the nearest
airport gateway fails the route tables
can be updated automatically to point to
the a back gateway in the other AZ so we
can achieve some high availability
through as well so next we look at
extending that our bank gateway
deployment across here at V pcs which is
the design adopted by our customer and
in the paired V PC there is a subnet
where the outbound gateway is deployed
now the route table for this subnet
contains an entry for The Parent
Connection which enables the outbound
gateway to establish the Giri tunnels
with the UTM workers then we have you
know one or more internal subnets and in
this case we've got one that contains
AWS workspaces but it could easily be
our other ec2 instances now the route
table for this subnet contains an entry
which of course points to its nearest
outbound gateway now in a workspaces
desktop or ec2 instance tries to connect
to the internet the packets are sent
first to the outbound gateway then
through the GRE tunnel which is up going
over the peering connection to the UTM
workers and then out to the Internet
so this is how the solution is able to
overcome the limitation of transitive
pairing so what were the outcomes as a
result of the solution adopted by our
customer they were able to achieve the
following outcomes firstly the overall
solution was able to bleed point using
cloud formation which supported their
deployment via code or infrastructure as
code requirement by using outbound
gateways the overall design was
simplified which significantly reduced
the number of UTM s required an initial
design included.you teams in each VP's C
so that was going to be significantly
increase the cost and complexity so by
using outbound gateways instead the U
teams were only required in one VP C
which was the Gateway VP see the u teams
were able to be configured to provide
the various security controls required
and in doing so achieved the governance
requirements resilience and self-healing
were achieved as the solution uses AWS
cloud watch so if a UTM was to fail a
replacement one would be launched
automatically in its place and auto
scaling was also used in the solution so
that the worker u teams if they started
to come under excessive load they could
Auto scale get the latest configuration
from that history bucket and handle the
increasing load are they going in or
coming out and finally one other benefit
of the solution is that it can also be
used to support ingress traffic if
required
